item.title: Biologizing the stack
item.description: I’m experimenting with writing some shorter, less polished posts. These come with the disclaimer that I’m optimizing for getting thoughts out there while they’re still crystallizing rather than achieving maximum rigor. For this post in particular, I’m not arguing that this direction is definitely worth pursuing so much as exploring a frame/idea to see where it gets me. A while ago, a friend asked me why I like the idea of working with cells better than cell-free systems and I gave some hand-wavy answer about cells being cool.

item.title: Continuous glucose monitors (CGM) and beyond: A dialogue
item.description: What are continuous glucose monitors good for? More broadly, what are continuous measures of physiology (CxM) good for? Similar to Elliot and I’s dialogue, this post has an unconventional format. It’s both a synthesis of Willy’s, Eryney’s, and my opinions on continuous monitoring combined with a debate in places where we disagree. To try and make it clear which views are coming from each person, we’ve annotated sections that come from a subset of us rather than all of us with e.

item.title: What are the bottlenecks to safe, repeatable edits in humans? Part 1
item.description: Summary # Gene editing has made a lot of progress over the past few decades. CRISPR-Cas9 sparked the recent fervor and won some of its early pioneers a Nobel Prize, and more recently Prime Editing and Cytosine/Adenine Base Editors (CBEs/ABEs) have further expanded the range of editing targets and types of edits that are possible while increasing efficiency and reducing the rate of off-target effects.
